1) the science of matter; the branch of the natural sciences dealing with the composition of substances and their properties and reactions
2) the chemical composition and properties of a substance or object
3) the way two individuals relate to each other

a mysterious alchemy brought them together

chemotaxis.definition: movement by a cell or organism in reaction to a chemical stimulus

2) informal terms for a meal

1) canvass by distributing letters

3) distribute circulars to

2) cause to become widely known
3) cause be distributed

examples.en: This letter is being circulated among the faculty
The air here does not circulate

1) the exercise of self constraint in sexual matters

contingency.definition: the state of being contingent on something

3) uncertain because of uncontrollable circumstances

1) occurring without interruption; chiefly restricted to what recurs regularly or frequently in a prolonged and closely spaced series

continuance.definition: the act of continuing an activity without interruption

3) keep or maintain in unaltered condition; cause to remain or last

I know it's hard," he continued, "but there is no choice

continuity.definition:
1) uninterrupted connection or union

continuous.definition:
1) continuing in time or space without interruption
2) of a function or curve; extending without break or irregularity

contour.definition:
1) form the contours of

contradict.definition:
1) be in contradiction with

1) opposition between two conflicting forces or ideas
2) (logic) a statement that is necessarily false
3) the speech act of contradicting someone

contradictory.definition:
1) of words or propositions so related that both cannot be true and both cannot be false

1) of words so related that one contrasts with the other

contribute.definition:
2) contribute to some cause
3) be conducive to

3) act of giving in common with others for a common purpose especially to a charity

2) the faculty of contriving; inventive skill
